def.p: (Friend virus susceptibility 1 locus). A genomic region in mice containing the Fv1 gene. Different Fv1 alleles encode versions of a restriction factor that protect mice from murine leukaemia viruses.

(PRRs). Host receptors (such as Toll-like receptors (TLRs) or NOD-like receptors (NLRs)) that can sense pathogen-associated molecular patterns and initiate signalling cascades that lead to an innate immune response. PRRs can be membrane bound (such as TLRs) or soluble cytoplasmic receptors (such as RIG-I, MDA5 and NLRs).
Selection to increase the frequency of mutations that confer a fitness advantage.
Mobile elements present in the genome that move locations using a mechanism involving reverse transcription.
A gene that is homologous to another gene within a species. Paralogues are generated through gene duplication and then divergence.
Changes in allele frequency that are due to genetic drift rather than a fitness outcome.

An evolutionary hypothesis proposed by Leigh Van Valen that states: “For an evolutionary system, continuing development is needed just in order to maintain its fitness relative to the systems it is co-evolving with.”

The ratio of the rate of non-synonymous mutations to the rate of synonymous mutations. Values greater than one are indicative of positive selection; values less than one are indicative of negative selection; and values near one are indicative of neutral selection.
A decrease in diversity in the genomic region surrounding an allele under positive selection.
Genetic linkage between loci under positive selection and nearby loci not under positive selection.
Selection to maintain polymorphism owing to frequency-dependent selection or heterozygote advantage.
Selection to maintain mutations at an intermediate frequency to confer a fitness advantage.
Homologous genes in different species that diverge after speciation.
